title: Interview candidates from PSL/open source policy community
description:
Potential interviewees from the open source policy simulation community:

## Matt Jensen (OSPC/AEI founder)
- Why did you start OSPC at AEI? What problem were you solving?
- How did you convince a think tank to fund open source infrastructure?
- What was the reception from JCT/CBO when you released Tax-Calculator?
- How has the relationship between official scorekeepers and open source models evolved?

## Martin Holmer (Tax-Calculator lead developer)
- You have decades of microsimulation experience and a PhD from MIT - what drew you to open source?
- What was the hardest part of building Tax-Calculator to production quality?
- Tell me about adapting Tax-Calculator for India with the World Bank
- How do you validate a model like this? What gives you confidence it's right?

## Jason DeBacker & Richard Evans (OG-USA)
- JCT/CBO/Treasury all use OG models - how did open source versions change the conversation?
- You've trained government staff in US, EU, India - what's the appetite for transparency?
- What can dynamic models tell us that static microsimulation can't?
- Where do you see the intersection of AI and OG modeling?

## Weifeng Zhong (Policy Change Index)
- Using NLP/ML to predict policy changes from government text - how accurate is it?
- PCI-China, PCI-Russia, PCI-North Korea - what patterns emerge?
- How does this complement traditional microsimulation?

## General questions for all:
- What does "open source" mean for policy credibility?
- Has open source changed how official scorers (JCT/CBO) operate?
- What's the biggest limitation of current models?
- Where does AI fit into the future of policy simulation?
